Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 01:58PM mich1224 wrote: Yes, I also need to start exercising.  I don't mind walking, so I will walk my son to Cub Scouts tonight instead of driving him the 4 blocks to his meeting.  It's a start.  I also have been trying to park in the further parking lot at work. Every little bit helps. I need to get in better shape for my surgery next month.  Jillisucat, I know where Blairstown is. Been there. Isn't Hot Dog Johnny's in a town near there? My husband loves that place. I used to live in Newton for 7 years before I moved to South Amboy.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 06:17PM mich1224 wrote: Jilliscat, my surgery is 2/6, not 2/4 if you want to correct.  Funny, I have 3 boys and a husband too.  I totally understand.  If I left for a month, the house would fall apart.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 11:18AM mich1224 wrote: I hear ya Jillisucat. My boys are 17, 14 and 10. My 17yr old usually does his own laundry but I can't get the 14yr old to try. At least I can get the 10yr old to empty the dishwasher. He's actually the most helpful. The kitchen garbage will be overflowing before I get stuck taking it out. (No one else notices this?) Thank goodness my mom will be taking time off work to help me out here. Although that means the rest of the family won't feel the need to do anything with her here. I'll owe her big time.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 03:03PM mich1224 wrote: Well, I made it. I had my bilat mx w/expanders on Friday. The worst day was Saturday, pain was awful. It gets a little better day by day, but is still there. I went to the doctor today, but drains are still outputting too much so they must stay in. I'm taking 1 vicodan every 4 hrs, since 2 at once made me feel funny in a way I didn't like. I'm going to start taking the valium tonight to sleep. I haven't gotten much since sleeping sitting up is hard, plus it hurts your back as well. Then there is the swelling near the underarms that just started today. Plus the itching. I'm also taking the antibiotics every 6hrs and now taking stool softener since still have not gone. Yes, the whole process stinks, but it does seem to get better everyday (thank goodness for that!) I keep trying to remember it will get better one day. It is awful that we must go thru this to get rid of the cancer.  Best wishes to all who have upcoming ops.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 10:15AM mich1224 wrote: I am schedule for bilateral mastectomy w/recon (explanders) on February 4th.  Good luck to everyone!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 06:23AM mich1224 wrote: Yes, for some reason the BS dr's don't want to prescribe meds for that. I tried with mine and got the same answer.  Thank goodness I work in the same office as my PCP so an appt was necessary. (that comes in handy)  And don't worry about complaining..we all do.  We're all under a lot of stress during this time.  My husband and kids will be lucky if they survive this ordeal.  Sometimes I just seem to snap at them when I normally wouldn't.  I hate that. Thank goodness for my mom. She is being so patient and understanding. In a house full of guys, having another woman a few days a week is needed. Thank goodness she'll be here after my surgery. The house would fall apart if she wasn't. My husband actually asked "who'll do the shopping after your surgery?" Gee, can't he pitch in? Men can't think sometimes. I can't wait until this is all behind us all!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 12:43PM mich1224 wrote: Yes, normal. My dx date was 10/24 and I am just getting to surgery 2/6. So, you're pretty quick. Although my delay was also due to MRI that I had to schedule as my dr wanted to be sure there were no other areas before she went in. Then the MRI showed areas that needed to be biopsied so I had to schedule MRI guided biopsies. Good thing too. The MRI biopsies found multiple areas of pre-cancerous cells in additional to the cancer area. You can imagine what a pain all the waiting is. It's the worst part.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s
How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 12:34PM mich1224 wrote: I had an MRI guided biopsy in December (both breasts).  I had a mammo and then biopsy on one breast which found cancer. Once that was found, my dr sent me for MRI to be sure there were no other areas before she did surgery. Well, the MRI showed suspicious areas in cancer breast and in the other. So...MRI guided biopsy was done which didn't find additional cancer, but did find areas in both breasts with atypical ductal hyperplasia. (I had this problem last year and had surgery-but it came back). Thus, I am having bilateral mastectomy on 2/6 with recon. As much as I am not looking forward to this, I am grateful she sent me for the MRI since the original mammo never showed anything in the opposite breast. I wish you the best in the days ahead. Think positive.
Posts.Title: Anyone have an MRI core Biopsy? I need one. shabby6485 green71364

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 01:20PM mich1224 wrote: Thank goodness for Oncotype testing. I was due to start chemo on a Thursday. My Oncologist only sent out for the testing because I was so hesitant to do chemo. She told me the only way I could change her mind, was if the test came back really low. Well, she called me Wednesday night to tell me I scored a 10. She was not expecting that and could no longer recommend chemo.  I dodged a bullett!  I still can't believe it.  To me, a bilat MX was enough to go through without the chemo.  I still have to do Tamoxifin, but so far I'm doing OK with it.
Posts.Title: Oncatype dx testing? Anxiousmama mich1224

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 02:29PM mich1224 wrote: I am also trying to decide whether to have recon or not.  I met with a PS today.  I am eligible for either implants or TRAM.  I am pretty set on no implants. I don't like the idea of them in me and knowing replacing will be needed every 10 yrs or so. (I'm only 45). That leaves me with TRAM which is the most involved. So, either lots of pain and longer recoup or no breasts. I think I can handle no breasts since I'm not that big to begin with (36B). My hubbie is fine with whatever, but quite a few family and friends feel I should have recon (I guess psychologically they feel I will feel better). So with most everyone saying I should have recon, I am more confused. No one says "I wouldn't have recon". This is the hardest decision. It helps though to read everyone's posts on this website.
